ev1511102302432.title: High Greenhouse Gases Concentration (RCP 8.5) Forecast
ev1511102302432.description:
Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) are four greenhouse gas concentration (not emissions) trajectories adopted by the IPCC for its fifth Assessment Report (AR5) in 2014. RCP 8.5 hypotheses high emission of greenhouse gases concentration.

NASA publishes long-term daily forecasts through their Earth Exchange platform for minimum and maximum air temperature and precipitations at .25° resolution through a cloud service using the NetCDF standard that also embeds metadata.

primary.author: Coro, G., Panichi, G., Scarponi, P., & Pagano, P.
primary.title: Cloud computing in a distributed e‐infrastructure using the web processing service standard
primary.reference: Concurrency and Computation: Practice and Experience, 29 (18)

ev1511105656982.title: IPCC SRES A1B Forecast
ev1511105656982.description:
Good quality annual forecasts have been produced by the AquaMaps Consortium based on the "IPCC SRES A1B scenario" of a future of rapid economic and global population growth that peaks in mid-century and declines thereafter, with a rapid introduction of new and more efficient technologies and a balance between fossil and non-fossil energy sources exploitation.

AquaMaps produces forecast data for 1950 (backwards forecast), 2050, and 2010 for six environmental parameters at .5° degrees resolution: Sea surface temperature, primary production, temperature at sea bottom level, sea surface salinity, salinity at sea bottom level, and ice concentration. They use a forecast model (IPSL) whose outputs are adjusted using real observation data from a number of sources, i.e. The World Ocean Atlas, NOAA NCEP Climatology, SeaAroundUs, and the US National Snow and Ice Data Centres. The AquaMaps environmental data are distributed in unstructured textual format through their Web site and metadata are available at a separate link in an online-excel sheet. Thus, processing is required to use these data in ecological modelling and climate change monitoring.

primary.author: Roeckner, E., Jungclaus, J., Mikolajewicz, U., & Hagemann, S
primary.title: Model Information of Potential Use to the IPCC Lead Authors and the AR4: ECHAM5_MPI-OM

text.headline: IPCC SRES A1B Forecast
text.text:
Good quality annual forecasts have been produced by the AquaMaps Consortium based on the "IPCC SRES A1B scenario" of a future of rapid economic and global population growth that peaks in mid-century and declines thereafter, with a rapid introduction of new and more efficient technologies and a balance between fossil and non-fossil energy sources exploitation.

AquaMaps produces forecast data for 1950 (backwards forecast), 2050, and 2010 for six environmental parameters at .5° degrees resolution: Sea surface temperature, primary production, temperature at sea bottom level, sea surface salinity, salinity at sea bottom level, and ice concentration. They use a forecast model (IPSL) whose outputs are adjusted using real observation data from a number of sources, i.e. The World Ocean Atlas, NOAA NCEP Climatology, SeaAroundUs, and the US National Snow and Ice Data Centres. The AquaMaps environmental data are distributed in unstructured textual format through their Web site and metadata are available at a separate link in an online-excel sheet. Thus, processing is required to use these data in ecological modelling and climate change monitoring.
Primary Sources
  • Roeckner, E., Jungclaus, J., Mikolajewicz, U., & Hagemann, S, Model Information of Potential Use to the IPCC Lead Authors and the AR4: ECHAM5_MPI-OM, www.pcmdi.llnl.gov/ipcc/model documentation/ipcc model documentation.php

NASA publishes long-term daily forecasts through their Earth Exchange platform for minimum and maximum air temperature and precipitations at .25° resolution through a cloud service using the NetCDF standard that also embeds metadata.

ev1511186230636.title: Climate Change
ev1511186230636.description:
This timeline presents the result of a data preparation and processing of Climate Change forecasts by AquaMaps and NASA through the CNR DataMiner Cloud Computing platform.

Forecasting environmental parameters in the far future requires complex modelling, large computational resources, fluid-dynamics processing applied to air and ocean currents information, correlating physical parameters (e.g. temperature, pressure, and wind), and involving human-related factors, e.g. greenhouse gases emission, energy resources exploitation etc. Thus, long-term forecasts data are rare and published by few organisations.

The history of Climate Change due to human activity can be dated back to the beginning of 1700 when the British ironmonger Thomas Newcomen invents the first widely used steam engine, paving the way for the Industrial Revolution and industrial scale use of coal. Due to the benefits brought by the industrial revolution, the World population reaches one billion in 1800. Thereafter, the history talks by itself.

It was only in 1990 that IPCC produced the First Assessment Report, concluding that temperatures have risen by 0.3-0.6 °C over the last century due to complementary greenhouse gases emission.

primary.author: Gianpaolo Coro
primary.title: Extracting General Patterns of Climate Change from Long-term Environmental Parameters Forecasts

primary.author: Richard Black
primary.title: A brief history of climate change

primary.author: Coro, G., Panichi, G., Scarponi, P., & Pagano, P.
primary.title: Cloud computing in a distributed e‐infrastructure using the web processing service standard
primary.reference: Concurrency and Computation: Practice and Experience, 29(18). http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpe.4219/pdf

text.headline: Climate Change
text.text:
This timeline presents the result of a data preparation and processing of Climate Change forecasts by AquaMaps and NASA through the CNR DataMiner Cloud Computing platform.

Forecasting environmental parameters in the far future requires complex modelling, large computational resources, fluid-dynamics processing applied to air and ocean currents information, correlating physical parameters (e.g. temperature, pressure, and wind), and involving human-related factors, e.g. greenhouse gases emission, energy resources exploitation etc. Thus, long-term forecasts data are rare and published by few organisations.

The history of Climate Change due to human activity can be dated back to the beginning of 1700 when the British ironmonger Thomas Newcomen invents the first widely used steam engine, paving the way for the Industrial Revolution and industrial scale use of coal. Due to the benefits brought by the industrial revolution, the World population reaches one billion in 1800. Thereafter, the history talks by itself.

It was only in 1990 that IPCC produced the First Assessment Report, concluding that temperatures have risen by 0.3-0.6 °C over the last century due to complementary greenhouse gases emission.
Primary Sources
  • Gianpaolo Coro, Extracting General Patterns of Climate Change from Long-term Environmental Parameters Forecasts, http://data.d4science.org/YkRxTThRV09FZ2ZueUlqUVo1cVVwNTZmUUhQUEl4V0dHbWJQNStIS0N6Yz0
  • Richard Black, A brief history of climate change, http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-15874560
  • Coro, G., Panichi, G., Scarponi, P., & Pagano, P., Cloud computing in a distributed e‐infrastructure using the web processing service standard, Concurrency and Computation: Practice and Experience, 29(18). http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpe.4219/pdf
  • D4Science e-Infrastructure, Climate Change Data Repository, http://thredds.d4science.org/thredds/catalog/public/netcdf/ClimateChange/catalog.html
Entities
climate change • Gianpaolo Coro • AquaMaps Consortium • Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche • National Aeronautics and Space Administration • A Brief History of Climate Change • DataMiner • climate change in popular culture • D4Science Climate Change Repository
